moves.1. e4: I call this Swindle and Shiester because of what happens near the end.  He gets swindle of all his remaining pieces in an fairly nice array of combo's. I play white.
Standard stuff thus far, just developing my pieces.
moves.7... O-O 8. Bxf6: Probably a dubious move, no real reason behind it...
moves.8... Bxf6 9. O-O b5 10. Bb3 Ba6 11. Ne2: He moves this pawn and leaves me a beauty square d5
moves.12. Bd5: There is no escape, the rook is going down.
moves.12... Nd7 13. Bxa8 Qxa8 14. c3 Qc6 15. d: Black is bringing his queen into dangerous territory...
moves.17. Re1 Qg6 18. cxd4 exd4 19. Nexd4 d5 2: Now the fireworks begin with the N-e5, forcing blacks Queen to move.
moves.23... Qd6: I don't want to lose my rook, even with the forking N it's not a win for white.
moves.24. Rxf7 Rf8 25. Nc4: This move exposes # on Qxg7, and if he takes RxR then I take his queen with N
moves.26. Rxf8+: Trading rooks to get his king where I want him.
moves.27... Qf6 28. Qxb8+ Kf7 29. Ne5+: Now he's forced to move onto the e-file where he's subject to a discovered check.
moves.30... Kf5 31. Nxf6 Kxf6: taking with King was not the correct response.
